 Approved By Tyler Smith Date
Department Head
Navigation and Unmanned Aircraft Systems Wallace N. Feerrar Date
Portfolio Manager
Navigation and Unmanned Aircraft Systems iii
 Executive Summary
The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) requested that The MITRE Corporation (MITRE) 
study alternative risk assessment methodologies and provide recommendations going forward to 
support the analysis and approvals of small unmanned aircraft system (sUAS) applications and 
provide the basis for risk-based decision making. This analysis includes detailed studies of two 
risk assessment methodologies exemplifying two different approaches. The MITRE-developed 
Small UAS Airworthiness Assessment Tool (sAAT) risk model, currently under development, is 
a quantitative probabilistic model. The Joint Authorities for Rulemaking on Unmanned Systems 
(JARUS) Specific Operations Risk Assessment (SORA) methodology, also under development, 
was selected to represent a knowledge-driven, qualitative risk assessment approach. Each model 
was selected based on the maturity of the development efforts as representative of the approach 
to risk modeling.
The sAAT risk model, developed in collaboration with industry and academia, is designed to 
calculate the risk of fatality per flight hour, based on aircraft characteristics, density of people 
exposed to the flight, reliability of the system, and aircraft kinetic energy (KE) in case of 
collision with a person. The risk to the third-party is calculated based on published measurements 
and coefficients for the aforementioned quantities. The benefit of the sAAT model is an explicit 
algorithm that can be validated and verified by other researchers. The sAAT ground risk model is 
undergoing testing and validation, and an air risk model is in development. The limitations of the 
sAAT model are primarily its narrow scope and limited set of input risk features. Complex or 
qualitative inputs, such as human error or onboard safety mitigations, are not included in the 
current model implementation.
In contrast, the SORA methodology, developed by Working Group 6 of the Joint Authorities for 
Rulemaking of Unmanned Systems (JARUS), is a rule-based, knowledge-driven system, whose 
risk inference methods are based on variables, rules, and relationships derived from subject 
matter experts. The SORA assessment results in a qualitative categorization of the operation into 
one of six different Specific Assurance and Integrity Levels (SAIL). It then recommends 
objectives to be met for each SAIL. The scope of risk factors being considered is broad and wide-
ranging. Compared to the sAAT risk model, the benefits of SORA are an expanded set of risk 
factors, the ability to incorporate a large variety of risk factor types (quantitative and qualitative) 
and unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) community model development. Limitations of SORA 
include the subjectivity of model inputs and complexity of the process. 
The goal of these models is to support an analysis that considers the combination of the aircraft 
and the intended mission, and provides an overall safety risk assessment of the operation from 
both the air and ground perspective.
The assessment of alternatives was based on a set of evaluation criteria, such as the complexity, 
scope, input parameters, outputs/results, risk factors examined, and mitigation factors examined. 
Based on the evaluation that follows, it is recommended that the FAA: Come to agreement on standardized safety thresholds and acceptable levels of risk to 1.
guide sUAS risk assessments.
Use a holistic review process such as the SORA (once finalized) or the FAA safety 2.
management system (SMS) assessment processes for those operations in the higher risk 
categories and/or with a required need for increased oversight.
Invest in the development of semi-automated functions when the SORA methodology is 3. iv
 finalized and standardize the wide variety of inputs and integration of standardized safety 
thresholds. 
Consider using the sAAT model to identify the operations with the lowest risk. These 4.
operations could be approved without further analysis. This may help streamline the 
approval process by reducing the number of applications that need more rigorous 
evaluation. 
Consider using the sAAT risk model to explore thresholds for acceptable levels of safety 5.
by examining the most sensitive parameters. Perform research to refine model parameter 
values and integrate and expand industry operational data. v
 Acknowledgments
The authors would like to acknowledge the technical contributions of the following people: Brian Patterson for background and expertise on the JARUS SORA risk assessment 
approach. Shereef Sayed, Norm Fenlason, and Laurence Audenaerd for their expertise and support 
on the MITRE Small UAS Airworthiness Tool (sAAT) risk model. Mike Noe for his subject matter expertise. vi

 Introduction1
With the rapid acceleration of small unmanned aircraft systems (sUAS) technology development 
and the ever-growing demand for sUAS operations in the National Airspace System (NAS), the 
Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is seeking risk assessment methods to enable increased 
airspace access to avoid restrictive operational or technical waivers. The FAA desires an 
evaluation approach that is timely and efficient to calculate the key risk factors in sUAS 
missions, and provide an actionable risk assessment in the form of an airworthiness approval. 
The approach should: Determine if the mission achieves the required level of safety
Indicate the highest risk contributors and, Identify the possible risk mitigations for excessive mission risk
Current risk assessment methods assume worst-case conditions wherein an sUAS failure would 
always achieve its maximum kinetic energy (KE) prior to impact and would always result in a 
collision with a third-party (uninvolved) individual on the ground or possible mid-air collision 
with a legacy manned aircraft. These worst-case assessments produce conservative risk estimates 
and limit the ability of the FAA to enable the growing demand for sUAS operations. Purpose1.1
The FAA requested that the MITRE Corporation (MITRE) evaluate alternative risk assessment 
methodologies to provide a recommendation for approving sUAS applications and provide the 
basis for risk-based decision making. This report contains an overview and comparison of two 
types of sUAS assessment methodologies, both of which are still in development: Joint Authorities for Rulemaking of Unmanned Systems (JARUS) Specific Operations 
Risk Assessment (SORA)
MITRE-developed Small UAS Airworthiness Assessment Tool (sAAT) This document details the basic requirements of a risk assessment model and its inputs and 
desired outcomes, as well as dimensions for comparisons. The purpose of this work is to inform 
the FAA on alternative risk assessment approaches to streamline and improve the accuracy of the 
airworthiness assessment process. 
The FAA typically certificates the airworthiness of the aircraft, certifies the qualification of the 
crew, and grants operational approval for the operation. This document does not distinguish 
which part of this process would be assessing risk as these risk methods could be applied to either 
the airworthiness of the aircraft or the safety of the operation. Approach1.2
MITRE compared the JARUS SORA approach to identify the similarities and differences with 
the sAAT risk model. The sAAT is a quantitative risk model that encompasses academic and 
industry knowledge and research along with aircraft and mission parameters to develop 
probabilistic risks of an sUAS collision with people on the ground (third-parties) which results in 
a fatality. 
The SORA approach was selected because of its standing with the international community. This ii
 qualitative approach uses a variety of non-numerical input and results in a risk assessment of 
relative operations. It has been under development with participation by many nation states and 
civil aviation authorities. 
The detailed studies of the two methodologies were used to identify the strengths and weaknesses 
of each approach. Using a set of evaluation criteria, MITRE compared the similarities and 
differences of the two methodologies, which informed the set of recommendations. i
 Risk Assessment2
Risk assessment is a systematic safety evaluation of a situation or activity. It involves the 
identification of hazards or vulnerabilities, along with an assessment of their likelihoods and 
severity. A formal model of a process or endeavor will expose and describe its hazards and 
consequences. Application of such a model enables a consistent and comprehensive assessment 
of risk factors, as well as
